postsData.name:
Rachel Park
Rachel Park
postsData.content:
Micromanagement is Killing Your Team's Wellbeing.
7 Shifts to Show Your Team You Care:

You see it in their eyes.
The spark of creativity dimming.
The energy draining day by day.

Micromanagement isn't just about control—
it's slowly eroding your team's mental health.

It shows up as:
→ Sunday night anxiety
→ Fear of making decisions
→ Constant second-guessing

But here's the thing:
Your team doesn't need more oversight.
They need psychological safety to thrive.

Here are 7 shifts to go from controlling to supporting your team:

1. Balance Support and Space
↳ Trust your team to navigate challenges before stepping in
↳ Be available for guidance while avoiding hovering over daily tasks

2. Build Trust Intentionally
↳ Demonstrate confidence in your team's judgment through actions, not words
↳ Support decisions made by team members, even if different from yours

3. Structure Feedback Flow
↳ Ask for honest input about your leadership style and impact
↳ Schedule regular check-ins that focus on support rather than surveillance

4. Master Strategic Delegation
↳ Assign tasks that align with each person's strengths and growth goals
↳ Give clear context for projects while avoiding prescriptive instructions

5. Create Open Dialogue
↳ Create safe spaces where team members can share concerns freely
↳ Build trust through consistent, transparent two-way communication channels

6. Set Clear Standards
↳ Define success metrics upfront so your team knows what matters
↳ Allow flexibility in how team members achieve these agreed outcomes

7. Encourage Creative Freedom
↳ Create space for new ideas by stepping back from detailed processes
↳ Celebrate innovative approaches, even when they differ from tradition


Your team's well-being matters more than control.

Trust them to shine their own way.

What's one shift you'll make this week? Share below 


 If you enjoyed this content, you might like my newsletter here:

___

 Follow mefor more posts on career & wellbeing.
️ Repost to support your network.

comments.commentText:
Bonus #2:
 Clear expectations and effective delegation reduce micromanagement and boost team performance. (Forbes)

Bonus #1:
 Micromanagement significantly increases employee stress, leading to burnout and disengagement. (Psychology Today)

postsData.commentAdded: Great insights! Fostering psychological safety is key to a thriving team. Ill focus on encouraging creative freedom this week!

postsData.name:
Bill Carmody, PCC
Bill Carmody, PCC
postsData.content:
Marketing Is Fuel

Another bonus of my keynote at VTEX, was that I got to meet and hang out with.

Like me, he was flown down to São Paulo, Brazil.

In his keynote address, he shared, "The best form of marketing isn't marketing. Think of marketing as fuel and imagine your product as a car. Assuming you have an amazing car, fuel will get you further."

That stuck with me and I’ve been using that insight ever since.

As a coach, when I’m working with my clients I never forget that the transformation with my clients is my product.

A post like this on LinkedIn is simply fuel to help remind others that I exist in the world and seek to serve my niche.

My ultimate “why” is simple: I’m here to eradicate scarcity and help every person tap into their infinite abundance.

Sharing this mission is the best fuel I can use to connect with others and help more coaches.

What’s your fuel?

If you like this post, please follow

comments.commentText: Bill Carmody, PCC, love this fuel analogy. When our mission truly ignites our passion, marketing flows naturally. Have you discovered what keeps your engine running smoothly?

Andrew Tallents Ah, yes. You want to know about the OIL . What keeps my engine running smoothly is my own mental fitness. My thoughts and my thoughts alone stop me from "Loving What Is" as Byron Katie would say

I agree with this -- I've always focused heavily on my product, knowing that when I deliver a great product and experience, that becomes the best form of marketing because it spreads by word of mouth!
Brynn Smith, CHPC And word of mouth is by far the best form of marketing, Brynn. You're totally right! Thanks for adding that insight to this post.

postsData.commentAdded: Love the analogy of marketing as fuel! Its a powerful reminder that our mission drives connections. Mine is empowering others to thrive! 🚀

postsData.name:
Matt Mosich
Matt Mosich
postsData.content:
“What you’re doing is risky.”

I hear this a lot.

Some mean well.

Others, not so much.

→ There aren’t many speaker coaches.
→ There aren’t many keynote speakers.
→ There are many struggling entrepreneurs.

I get it.

But, where most saw risk, I saw the only path.

Because this statement ignores an important fact.

Accepting a life you don’t enjoy is risky too.

Far more I’d argue.

Because, it’s accepting regret.

And, that’s something that you’ll always live with.

P.S. What do you think is the bigger risk?
postsData.commentAdded: Absolutely! Embracing passion over fear is vital. Living with regret is the true risk. Let’s dare to follow our dreams! #FearlessLiving

Job Seekers - your LinkedIn About section should 𝗡𝗢𝗧 be AI-generated buzz words.

Here's what it should say 

First - I want to remind you of something my coach taught me.

Facts tell.

Stories sell.

When you're seeking a job you're selling a product.

And 𝗬𝗢𝗨 are the product.

Here's some examples of things you 𝘀𝗵𝗼𝘂𝗹𝗱𝗻'𝘁 do:

 Writing in the third person to describe yourself.

 Writing cliche buzz phrases like "streamlining operational efficiency."

 An exhaustive list of certifications & degrees.

It sounds like everyone else.

It's uninspiring.

And it falls flat with your audience.

The About section is your opportunity to tell a story.

It's where you differentiate yourself from everyone else's cliche, buzzword-filled profile.

Here's what it 𝘀𝗵𝗼𝘂𝗹𝗱 say:

 What's unique about you.

 A pivotal moment in your life that led you to where you are now.

 Who you can help.

Here's an example to iterate from,

"Life felt boring and meaningless until I found my purpose. Now, I wake up full of energy and life, inspired to help job seekers land the job of their dreams."

That stands out a heck of a lot more than,

"Seasoned IT professional with a track record of enhancing stakeholder buy-in"

You're a unique individual.

Your LinkedIn About section should be also 

______________

️ Repost to help a job seeker.

postsData.name:
Fatou Seck Mathon
Fatou Seck Mathon
postsData.content:
7 worst things to do when exiting an employee.
(and how to handle it to preserve their dignity).

Letting someone go is not just a business decision.

It's a critical moment that impacts their life.

Handled poorly, it damages trust, team's morale, and your reputation.

Here are the 7 worst things to do when exiting an employee:
(and how to handle it to protect their dignity)

1. Being cold and impersonal:
 Treating someone like just another name on a spreadsheet.
 Acknowledge their contributions and recognize their work.

2. Rushing through it:
 Delivering the news quickly and moving on.
 Give them time to process and stay available.

3. Choosing the wrong timing:
 Giving them the bad news on a Friday or before a holiday.
 Pick a time when they have space to plan their next steps.

4. Making it public:
 Asking them to pack their things in front of everyone.
 Provide privacy. Let them leave with dignity.

5. Offering zero support:
 Saying "Good luck" and walking away.
 Offer guidance, career resources, or a recommendation.

6. Sounding robotic:
 Reading from a script and avoiding eye contact.
 Speak honestly. Show that you care.

7. Ignoring team impact:
 Pretending nothing happened while your team is in shock.
 Be transparent. Address concerns and reassure your team.

Treat people the way you want to be treated.

Lead with empathy, even in the hardest moments.

What would you add as the worst thing to do?


Repost to help a leader exit employees with empathy.
Followfro more.

comments.commentText: Letting someone go is never just a process; it’s a defining leadership moment that reveals your true character. Great insights, Fatou Seck Mathon! The way you handle an exit speaks volumes about the message it sends to those who stay.
comments.userName: Damesha Craig, Leadership Coach and Startup Advisor

postsData.commentAdded: This is a crucial topic! Prioritizing empathy during exits fosters trust and maintains morale. It’s the human touch that truly matters.

postsData.name:
Machine Learning Community (Moderated)
Machine Learning Community (Moderated)
postsData.content:
DeepSeek vs ChatGPT: Key Differences

1. Developer
DeepSeek AI: Developed as an open-source LLM.
ChatGPT: Proprietary model developed by OpenAI.

2. Model Type
DeepSeek AI: Mixture-of-Experts (MoE) architecture.
ChatGPT: Transformer-based (GPT-4).

3. Training Data
DeepSeek AI: Multilingual with a strong focus on Chinese.
ChatGPT: Extensive multilingual training, with strong performance in English.

4. Performance
DeepSeek AI: Efficient and cost-effective, optimized for coding and technical tasks.
ChatGPT: Excels in reasoning, creativity, and text coherence.

5. Strengths
DeepSeek AI: Best for coding, programming, and technical applications.
ChatGPT: Ideal for conversational AI, creative writing, and coding assistance.

[Explore more in the post]

postsData.commentAdded: Great comparison! Each model has its unique strengths—excited to see how they continue to evolve in the AI landscape! #AI #MachineLearning

postsData.content:
𝗧𝗵𝗲 𝗛𝗮𝗿𝘀𝗵 𝗥𝗲𝗮𝗹𝗶𝘁𝘆 𝗳𝗼𝗿 𝗦𝗮𝗹𝗲𝘀 𝗧𝗲𝗮𝗺𝘀 

𝗪𝗵𝗲𝘁𝗵𝗲𝗿 𝘆𝗼𝘂’𝗿𝗲 𝗮𝗻 𝗔𝗘, 𝗦𝗗𝗥, 𝗼𝗿 𝘀𝗮𝗹𝗲𝘀 𝗹𝗲𝗮𝗱𝗲𝗿, 𝘁𝗵𝗲 𝗴𝗿𝗶𝗻𝗱 𝗶𝘀 𝗿𝗲𝗮𝗹. The pressure to hit quotas, navigate complex deals, and juggle multiple accounts never stops.

 𝗛𝗶𝗴𝗵 𝗰𝗮𝗹𝗹 𝘃𝗼𝗹𝘂𝗺𝗲, 𝗹𝗼𝘄 𝘀𝘂𝗰𝗰𝗲𝘀𝘀 𝗿𝗮𝘁𝗲𝘀 – Constant outreach with too few real conversations.
 𝗖𝗼𝗻𝘀𝘁𝗮𝗻𝘁 𝗰𝗼𝗻𝘁𝗲𝘅𝘁-𝘀𝘄𝗶𝘁𝗰𝗵𝗶𝗻𝗴 – Jumping between industries, accounts, and buyer personas.
 𝗦𝗰𝗮𝘁𝘁𝗲𝗿𝗲𝗱 𝗶𝗻𝘀𝗶𝗴𝗵𝘁𝘀 – Critical call data and notes aren’t captured in one place, making follow-ups harder.

 𝗛𝗼𝘄 𝗜𝗻𝘀𝘆𝗴𝗵𝘁𝗳𝘂𝗹 𝗔𝗜 𝗖𝗵𝗮𝗻𝗴𝗲𝘀 𝘁𝗵𝗲 𝗚𝗮𝗺𝗲

Sales teams need real-time insights and automation to work smarter, not harder. Here’s how:

 𝗜𝗻𝗳𝗹𝘂𝗲𝗻𝗰𝗲 𝗛𝗶𝗲𝗿𝗮𝗿𝗰𝗵𝘆 𝗠𝗮𝗽𝗽𝗶𝗻𝗴 – No more guessing who the key decision-makers are.
 𝗟𝗶𝘃𝗲 𝗔𝗜-Powered Objection Handling – Reps get real-time responses to navigate objections with confidence.
 𝗟𝗶𝘃𝗲 𝗖𝗼𝗮𝗰𝗵𝗶𝗻𝗴 & 𝗧𝗿𝗮𝗻𝘀𝗰𝗿𝗶𝗽𝘁𝗶𝗼𝗻 – Managers can see calls unfold and provide instant feedback when it counts.
 𝗦𝗲𝗮𝗺𝗹𝗲𝘀𝘀 𝗦𝗮𝗹𝗲𝘀𝗳𝗼𝗿𝗰𝗲 𝗜𝗻𝘁𝗲𝗴𝗿𝗮𝘁𝗶𝗼𝗻 – Insights, notes, and action items sync automatically—eliminating manual data entry.

𝗟𝗲𝘁’𝘀 𝗠𝗮𝗸𝗲 𝗜𝘁 𝗬𝗼𝘂𝗿𝘀

Your company’s playbook can be 𝗶𝗺𝗽𝗼𝗿𝘁𝗲𝗱 𝗱𝗶𝗿𝗲𝗰𝘁𝗹𝘆 into Insyghtful AI, making it live during calls. No flipping through scripts—just 𝗿𝗲𝗮𝗹-𝘁𝗶𝗺𝗲, 𝗔𝗜-𝗱𝗿𝗶𝘃𝗲𝗻 𝗴𝘂𝗶𝗱𝗮𝗻𝗰𝗲, fully integrated with Salesforce.

Want to see it in action? Please drop a comment or DM me. Let’s elevate your sales team.
postsData.commentAdded: Great insights! Embracing AI can truly transform sales strategies. Excited to see how Insyghtful AI can empower teams for success! 🚀

postsData.name:
James R. Elliot
James R. Elliot
postsData.content:
How to Avoid Burnout and Build a Business You Love

Being an entrepreneur doesn’t have to mean sacrificing your health, energy, or happiness. Yet, many find themselves stuck in the trap of hustle and grind, building businesses they end up resenting.

The key to long-term success is working smarter, not harder. Here’s how to avoid burnout and create a business you truly love.

The Trap of the Corporate Grind

I realized the mindset of working nonstop to prove your worth was ingrained in me. The constant “hustle, hustle, hustle” mentality teaches us that success equals hard work.

The Cost of Not Reworking Your Business

Many entrepreneurs fall into the trap of creating businesses they later feel trapped by. Overworking, burnout, and poor health become common outcomes. The very reason many start businesses—freedom and lifestyle—gets lost in the chaos of never-ending to-do lists.

The Risk of Staying in the Same Pattern

Without self-reflection and adjustments, entrepreneurs risk staying stuck in the same exhausting cycle. It’s crucial to rethink your business structure and mindset to avoid ongoing struggles.

Signs of Burnout and How to Address It

Burnout can sneak up on you. Many don’t realize they’re heading toward burnout until it’s too late. To address this, identify the tasks you love and those that drain you.

Delegate or automate the draining ones. Outsourcing can be scary, but it can give you back your time and energy when done right.

Practical Tips to Restructure Your Business

Automate or eliminate low-value tasks.

Focus on what truly drives growth.

Start small—small tweaks can lead to big changes.

Building a business you love starts with working smarter, not harder.

Prioritize your well-being and watch your business thrive.
postsData.commentAdded: Great insights! Rethinking our approach is essential. Prioritizing well-being truly paves the way for sustainable success. #WorkSmart #Entrepreneurship

postsData.name:
steven kamensky
steven kamensky
postsData.content:
Happy Sunday, everyone!  This day is a gift—an opportunity to pause, reflect, and realign. Take a moment to think about the week that’s just passed. What went well? What could have gone better? Celebrate your victories, no matter how big or small, and recognize the lessons learned from the challenges. Growth comes from both success and struggle.
As we head into the upcoming week, let’s take time to plan with intention. What are the goals you want to achieve? How can you show up as the best version of yourself? Whether it’s in your work, personal growth, or relationships, set a positive mindset for the days ahead.
But don’t forget, Sundays are also about balance. It’s so easy to get caught up in the hustle, but today, make sure you’re taking time to reset and recharge. Be present with the people you love. Laugh, share stories, and create memories. Those moments with family and friends are precious and can fill your heart with the energy you need to tackle the week.
Let today be a reminder that rest is just as important as productivity. Find your calm, refresh your spirit, and step into the new week with purpose and peace. 
Here’s to a fresh start, to setting new intentions, and to making the most of every moment with those who matter most. Have an amazing week ahead!

postsData.name:
Marsden Kline
Marsden Kline
postsData.content:
A title doesn't make you a leader.

Your actions do.

Stop waiting for permission to lead.
Lean into these habits that make work easier:

1. Raise the energy of the room
↳ Enter with purpose
↳ Eyes up, phones down

2. Be easy to work with
↳ Make someone's job easier every day
↳ Replace "someone should" with "I will"

3. Have the courage to say no
↳ Set boundaries without guilt
↳ Choose what matters, cut what doesn't

4. Keep your commitments
↳ Make tiny promises, keep them religiously
↳ Build trust through consistent delivery

5. Write strategically
↳ Turn complex ideas into simple messages
↳ Author team updates before being asked

6. Be relentlessly resourceful
↳ Fix small problems others complain about
↳ Create value before anyone requests it

7. Solve problems with selling
↳ Turn customer problems into clear plans
↳ Show the impact in simple numbers

8. Learn how to learn
↳ Study one new part of the business daily
↳ Turn "I don't know" into "I'll find out"

9. Actively listen
↳ Make others feel deeply understood
↳ Ask questions that open new possibilities

Remember:

Leadership isn't given. It's earned.
One small action at a time

️ Share to help someone
 Followfor more

Carousel by

comments.commentText:
The habits you’ve outlined are foundational to becoming the type of person others naturally follow, regardless of role or rank. Here’s my take on a few:

- Raise the energy of the room: Leaders are emotional thermostats, not thermometers. Your attitude sets the tone for others to follow.

- Keep commitments: Trust is your greatest currency as a leader. Even small broken promises compound into doubt—but small kept promises build loyalty.

- Be relentlessly resourceful: Show initiative. Solve problems proactively, even if they’re outside your scope. This “ownership mindset” is what separates leaders from the crowd.
Joel - love your take on leaders as emotional thermostats and the power of keeping small promises. What’s one habit you’ve found most transformative in building trust and loyalty?
Thanks! I'd have to say practicing proactive transparency. Sharing relevant context with your team, especially the “why” behind decisions, instantly builds trust.
As someone who values proactive problem-solving, I find the idea of being relentlessly resourceful particularly powerful.
Anubrota - many stop at the first resistance. Others remain curious and find a way to solve for yes.

postsData.commentAdded: Absolutely agree! Leadership is about actions and impact. Let’s all strive to lead by example and uplift those around us! 💪✨

postsData.name:
Chelsea Olsen

postsData.content:
I do this weird thing…

 𝗪𝗵𝗲𝗿𝗲 𝗜 𝗴𝗼 𝘁𝗼 𝗮𝗹𝗹 𝗼𝗳 𝘆𝗼𝘂𝗿 𝗟𝗶𝗻𝗸𝗲𝗱𝗜𝗻 𝗽𝗿𝗼𝗳𝗶𝗹𝗲𝘀 𝗮𝗻𝗱 𝗿𝗲𝘄𝗿𝗶𝘁𝗲 𝘆𝗼𝘂𝗿 𝗵𝗲𝗮𝗱𝗹𝗶𝗻𝗲𝘀 𝗶𝗻 𝗺𝘆 𝗵𝗲𝗮𝗱.

(𝘛𝘩𝘦𝘯 𝘳𝘦𝘴𝘪𝘴𝘵 𝘵𝘩𝘦 𝘶𝘳𝘨𝘦 𝘵𝘰 𝘋𝘔 𝘺𝘰𝘶 𝘢𝘣𝘰𝘶𝘵 𝘪𝘵.)

Because 90% of you speak in riddles.

1. Your profile is like a game of Clue
2. OR it’s actually a game of Clueless

Because most people who land on your page…

𝘏𝘢𝘷𝘦 𝘯𝘰 𝘤𝘭𝘶𝘦 𝘸𝘩𝘢𝘵 𝘺𝘰𝘶 𝘥𝘰.

𝗣𝗲𝗼𝗽𝗹𝗲 𝘀𝗵𝗼𝘂𝗹𝗱𝗻'𝘁 𝗵𝗮𝘃𝗲 𝘁𝗼 𝗴𝘂𝗲𝘀𝘀:

- Who you help
- How you help them
- What problem you solve

They should know within 𝟱 𝘀𝗲𝗰𝗼𝗻𝗱𝘀 of reading your headline what you are selling.

If your LinkedIn profile reads like a riddle,

You’re making it hard to get leads.

Make it easy.

P.S. Drop your headline in the comments and tell me what you sell.

I’ll give my feedback for free.

comments.commentText:
Now that you mention it, I can see mine is pretty terrible. Thank you for helping! 
Currently it reads:
Jungian Life Coach & Innovator | Shaping tools and insights to guide clients to breakthroughs in relationships, leadership, and life.

What I actually do is help people develop dormant parts of their personality and turn their crap into gold. Can you help me communicate that? Thank you so much!

postsData.commentAdded: Great insight! A clear headline can make all the difference. 💡 Let’s simplify our messaging and attract the right connections! 🌟

postsData.name:
Yathaash Fulwadiwala
Yathaash Fulwadiwala
postsData.content:
Looking back, there are lessons that would’ve saved me time, pain and self-doubt.

But hey, life’s about learning, right?

Each of these aspects hit hard in it's own time and each one shaped me into who I am today.

The good news?

You don’t have to wait to learn the hard way.

Start embracing these important aspects now, and you’ll thank yourself later.

Which of these hits home for you?
Let me know in the comments below.

If you’re ready to take responsibility for your life, master your mindset, and lead with unshakable confidence, DM me ‘Guide’, and I’ll send you my 7-Day Masculinity Blueprint to get started.

For daily tools to step into your full potential,
Follow


.
.

comments.commentText: For me it is point no. 4. The people you surround yourself with will define your future Yathaash Fulwadiwala . The right circle always matter. They cheer us, push us, lead us and enable us to be our best version.

Sourish Bujarbaruah  Absolutely! Your circle can either lift you higher or hold you back. 

Surrounding yourself with the right people is key to growth and success.

It makes all the difference!

postsData.commentAdded: Empowering reflections! Embracing these lessons early makes a world of difference. Excited to see others share their experiences! 💪

postsData.content: Please share your thoughts on Artificial Intelligence and your company's maturity stage. This data will be used to finalize my doctoral dissertation and potentially lead to additional post-doctoral research. I am also looking for 3 - 5 individuals who would be willing to speak to me in a scheduled Teams chat to discuss a few of your answers in more detail.
